Though Charles II formally reprieved him, a Royalist court pursued him literally to the death. He was beheaded on Tower Hill and buried at Fairlawne in Shipbourne, which his father had settled on him.

Sir Thomas Peyton, 2nd Baronet (1613-84)

Only nine when he inherited his father Sir Samuel Peyton‘s estate, including his title and the traditional family seat Knowlton Court, Goodnestone, Peyton looked set for a comfortable life when, having married well, he became MP for Sandwich in 1640. These were dangerous times, however, and as a Royalist he was ejected from Parliament in 1644. He joined a group of radicals intent on overthrowing the revolutionary regime, and so was imprisoned in the Tower. Cromwell showed he had a compassionate side, however, when in 1655 he ordered that Peyton be allowed to spend 36 days at the Tunbridge Wells spa, presumably to recover his health. After the Restoration, Peyton was elected MP for Kent in the so-called Cavalier Parliament; but, despite being handed remunerative positions, he died deeply in debt. Consequently, his daughters were obliged to sell the estate to Admiral Sir John Narborough. He was buried in Westminster Abbey.

John Lilburne (ca 1614-57)

The Civil War was the last time England was divided fiercely down arbitrary lines, republican sentiment was rife, radical beliefs became mainstream, and moral principle justified mass expropriation. One protagonist was John Lilburne, born (probably) in Greenwich of minor gentry from County Durham. He became prominent as a pamphleteer publicising the most extreme beliefs of the Levellers movement, whose aim was to press the same status on everyman. He invented the concept of ‘freeborn rights’ – privileges enjoyed by all by dint of being alive. The idea was unacceptable even to fellow anti-monarchists, but proved useful to American revolutionaries, and has now been recycled around the world. Though he fought in the Parliamentary army and remained highly popular with Londoners, Lilburne’s militancy won him few friends in authority. He was flogged, exiled, and repeatedly jailed, finally in Dover Castle. There he was converted to Quakerism. ‘Freeborn John’ spread the word around Kent, but died while visiting his wife at Eltham.

John Wallis (1616-1703)

A reverend’s son who himself became a reverend, John Wallis was born in Ashford, but after a plague outbreak attended grammar school in Tenterden. He studied at Cambridge, but from 1649 became a geometry professor at Oxford until his death. A mathematical genius, he made contributions in several other fields, including infinitesimal calculus and trigonometry. His most significant work, ‘Arithmetica Infinitorum’ (1656), introduced the Wallis Product, a new expression of π. He introduced the infinity symbol ∞ and multiplication sign x. Although he served Parliament as a cryptographer for 46 years, he supported the Restoration, and was a founder of the Royal Society in 1660. While responding to a Royal Society challenge in 1668, he identified conservation of momentum, and coined the term ‘momentum’. An insomniac, Wallis did mental calculations in bed, and once reeled off the 27-digit root of a 53-digit number over breakfast. An asteroid and an academy are named after him, as was an Ashford pub.

Dorothy Spencer, Countess of Sunderland (1617-84)

The daughter of the Earl of Leicester, Dorothy Sidney from Penshurst became famous less for what she wrote, which amounted to her eloquent correspondence, than what was written about her. Known for her aristocratic beauty, she ignited a flame in the poet Edmund Waller, a relative of the Kentish Parliamentarian commanders William and Hardress Waller. Such was his passion that he wrote 16 genteel love-poems for her; he named her ‘Sacharissa’, which might translate today as something like ‘Sugarplum’. She virtuously shunned the lovelorn Waller’s advances, although in truth she had fatter fish to fry. At 21, she married the Earl of Sunderland at Penshurst, so becoming Lady Dorothy Spencer and living at Althorp House in Northamptonshire. Her husband was killed at the First Battle of Newbury in 1643, however, so she returned at length to Penshurst Place. In 1926, Julia Cartwright Ady wrote a biography of her, aptly named ‘Sacharissa’.

Francis Lovelace (ca 1621-75)

Lovelace’s father Sir William owned properties at both Bethersden and Woolwich. Like his four brothers, including the ‘Cavalier poet’ Richard, Francis fought for the King in the Civil War, commanding Carmarthen Castle as a colonel until its capture by Parliament in 1645, when another brother, William, was killed. Following exile in France, he joined his sister Anne in Virginia, but was sent home and jailed in the Tower after Parliamentarians arrived. He returned to America after the Restoration, when the Duke of York appointed him the second governor of New York. He took his responsibilities seriously: he improved defences, formed a militia, paid the native Lenape for Staten Island, and introduced religious freedoms, all while running the ‘Lovelace’ Tavern in Manhattan. When he was away working to establish a postal service, however, the Dutch seized the colony, albeit temporarily. The vindictive Duke held Lovelace responsible, sequestered his assets, and returned him to the Tower. Stricken by dropsy, he died penniless.

Sir John Banks, 1st Baronet (1627-99)

Banks, the son of a Maidstone gentleman trader, went to Cambridge before becoming a merchant supplying hops and grain. By the age of 30, well on his way to becoming one of the wealthiest men in England, he had married the Lord Mayor of London’s daughter and bought The Friars at Aylesford; he later added a smart townhouse in Lincoln’s Inn Fields. Having briefly served as governor of the East India Company during the costly Third Dutch War, he co-funded efforts to discover a North-East passage with his close friend at the Admiralty, Samuel Pepys, who as godfather to Banks’s son Caleb arranged for John Locke, no less, to accompany the boy on a Grand Tour. Banks was made a baronet in 1661, and became a Fellow of the Royal Society in 1668. An MP in 11 parliaments spanning 45 years, he represented Winchelsea, Rochester, and Queenborough, remarkably book-ended by Maidstone in both his twenties and seventies.

Sir Paul Rycaut (1629-1700)

After reaching the walls of Vienna in 1529, the Ottoman Empire remained a major threat to Europe well into the C17. In 1660, Charles II sent Heneage Finch, the 3rd Earl of Winchelsea of Eastwell Manor, to serve as ambassador in Turkey. His secretary was Paul Rycaut from The Friary, Aylesford, a Cambridge graduate of Huguenot descent, who was later appointed the Levant Company’s consul in Smyrna, and also turned out a fine scholar. In 1665, he published ‘The Present State of the Ottoman Empire’, to which he added an account of the Orthodox Churches of Armenia and Greece (1679). He followed up in 1687 with his monumental ‘The Turkish History’ in two volumes. By that time, the Islamic tide had turned, the Ottomans having been decisively defeated at the Battle of Vienna in 1683, although Ottoman slave-traders continued to plague Europe until the C20. A fellow of the Royal Society, Rycaut retired to Hamburg, but was buried at Aylesford.

John Spencer (1630-93)

Having been born in Boughton-under-Blean, Spencer went to The King’s School, Canterbury and benefited from an Archbishop Parker scholarship at Corpus Christi, Cambridge. In 1667, he became master of the College, which he remained for 26 years until his death. Meanwhile, he proceeded up the ecclesiastical ladder to the post of dean of Ely in 1677, at which cathedral he was eventually buried. In 1663, he had published a book on marvels that Samuel Pepys described as “most ingeniously writ”. He earned notoriety, however, for a controversy over his magnum opus ‘De Legibus Hebraeorum’ (1685), a scholarly work arguing that Mosaic Law was not original but derived from Egyptian tradition. Since this directly contradicted the Bible, he was attacked from all directions, even from abroad. Despite being described as “dangerous” in a C19 index of English literature, the book set an example for further such works of comparative religion. Spencer’s complete works were published in 1717.

Margaret Finch (1632?-1740)

A two-hour ride from London, ‘Beggar’s Hill’ at Norwood, Surrey was for 200 years such a popular rural draw to Roma gypsies that it was renamed Gipsy Hill; Samuel Pepys paid a visit, and John Keats wrote a poem about it. In 1768, the gypsies there elected Margaret Finch from Sutton, Kent their new queen. She exercised matriarchal control over her kinsfolk, while making a living by whatever means presented themselves, which primarily meant fortune-telling. Although exploiting people’s superstitious beliefs may sound reprehensible to the modern ear, it might better be thought of as entertainment. She obviously perfected an impressive act, because she supposedly ended up wealthy. She is said to have died at 108, although this is unverifiable. Described in old age as “grotesque”, she spent so long hunched up with her pipe and her lap-dog in her hut made of branches that muscle contracture locked her bones in place. She was buried at Beckenham in a square coffin.

Sir Charles Sedley, 5th Baronet (1639-1701)

The son of Sir John Sedley of The Friars, Aylesford, Charles came to the public’s attention for all the wrong reasons. Having left Oxford without a degree, he joined the licentious Merry Gang in London, and was fined for standing naked on a balcony before a large crowd, pouring a glass of wine, stirring it inappropriately, and drinking the King’s health. Samuel Pepys declared him a “famous fop” and lover of actress Peg Hughes. Two decades later, better known as a playwright, poet, and MP for New Romney, Sedley quipped that, as the King’s successor James II had controversially made his daughter Catherine Sedley a countess after impregnating her, he might reciprocate by making James’s daughter Mary a queen. His wish was fulfilled when the King was deposed in the Glorious Revolution, Mary succeeded him, and Sedley was knighted. Denied a divorce after his wife went mad, Sedley also had two illegitimate sons by his long-term mistress, Ann Ayscough.

Sir Streynsham Master (1640-1724)

Born at Langdon, Dover, Master joined the East India Company early, first running EIC operations in Gujarat before moving on to Andhra Pradesh and Bengal. In 1678, he took over from Sir William Langhorne as the agent of Madras. Like Langhorne, he faced local panjandrums’ demands for tribute which, being liable to progress from diplomatic threat to military shove, underscored the need for the EIC to defend itself. Master nevertheless brought to his work a Christian ethic that would become a hallmark of the Raj. During his time there, St Mary’s church was built, the first in Madras. He was the first to tackle one of several Indian customs that outraged Britons, when he intervened in 1680 to save a local woman from suttee, i.e. being burned alive on her husband’s funeral pyre. He also appointed ‘scavengers’, customs collectors who were responsible for cleaning up the streets. After leaving in 1681, he bought a castle in Derbyshire.

Dr Robert Plot (1640-96)

Robert Plot ought to be world famous as the man who published the very first illustration of a dinosaur bone, two centuries before the discovery of Maidstone’s famous ‘iguanadon’. Unfortunately for Plot, the only authority on creation in his day was the Bible; so he misinterpreted the fossil of a megalosaurus’s femur in his ‘Natural History of Oxfordshire’ (1677) as, if not a natural geological formation, then a giant’s thighbone. Not that he was a fool. Born in Borden, he had gone to school in Wye before attending Oxford, where in 1683 he became the first curator and Professor of Chemistry at the Ashmolean Museum, whilst simultaneously serving as Secretary of the Royal Society. He completed a ‘Natural History of Staffordshire’ (1686) before turning to a volume on Middlesex & Kent that was unfinished when he died back in Borden. He is commemorated with a plaque at the local church.

Aphra Behn (1640-89)

The enigmatic Aphra Behn from Canterbury (or maybe Wye) could be famous for her cool name alone. She wasn’t actually that exotic: Aphra was a biblical name, like Keturah or Keziah, and her maiden name was probably Johnson, unless it was Cooper. She acquired the Behn from a Dutchman, who may actually have been German. She supposedly spied for King Charles II but reported only untruths. We do know that, being Catholic, she injudiciously supported the doomed King James II. She responded to her impoverished condition by expressing herself prodigiously in print. She was forgotten until Virginia Woolf praised her for being a female writer, after which Behn was lionised by numerous feminist commentators. Some blamed prudish Victorians for her oblivion, although others think she just wasn’t much cop. Another feminist, Germaine Greer, had the last word, describing her as a palimpsest: a blank sheet onto which later generations project their own prejudices. Either that, or she wasn’t.

Mary Carleton (1642-73)

For centuries after the Norman Conquest, a woman’s best chance of making a fortune, short of inheriting one, was to marry a rich man, survive multiple childbirths, and outlive him, whether he died in battle or of excess. Mary Moders from Canterbury considered it too much trouble, and decided instead on a life of crime. She was first convicted of bigamy at Maidstone after marrying a Dover surgeon while wed to a Canterbury shoemaker. She headed for Cologne, where she beguiled an aristocrat with the promise of marriage, milked him of gifts, and scarpered. Back in London, she was acquitted of posing as a German princess to entrap surgeon John Carleton, which inspired a book and a play about her. A series of frauds followed, usually involving the pretence of being an heiress. Convicted of theft, she was transported to Jamaica, where she became a prostitute. After returning illegally to London, she was arrested, tried, and hanged at Tyburn.

The Very Reverend Thomas Comber (1645-99)

For the first four years of his life, Comber from Westerham never knew his father, who had fled to the Low Countries as a refugee from the Civil War. The boy proved an outstanding scholar, who already knew Greek by the age of ten and went on to receive a wide education. He went into the Church, eventually marrying and settling in Yorkshire. In 1672, he published ‘A Companion to the Temple and Closet’, with which he hoped to assuage Protestant nonconformists. It was one of many learned works he wrote with the aim of enlightening the pious and not so pious in that fraught age. Matters became even fraughter in 1688, however, when the Catholic king James II proposed a Catholic archbishop of York over Comber’s head. Luckily for him, the Glorious Revolution came to his rescue. Having published two pamphlets in support of it, he was installed as the dean of Durham in 1691.

Admiral of the Fleet Sir George Rooke (1650-1709)

George Rooke was born at Lawrence House, Canterbury, the seat of his father Colonel Sir William Rooke. In 1672, when the 3rd Dutch War broke out, he volunteered for the Royal Navy. It was a baptism of fire, as he repeatedly faced the formidable Dutch admiral de Ruyter. He survived, and in 1677, now a captain, brought Prince William of Orange to England. Early in the Nine Years War (1688-97), he became a rear admiral, distinguishing himself by burning 12 French warships at the Battle of La Hogue (1692), for which he was knighted. During the War of the Spanish Succession (1701-14), he captured or destroyed all the Spanish treasure ships and the escorting French fleet at Vigo Bay, and two years later took Gibraltar, where he is now commemorated with a statue. He subsequently became Admiral of the Fleet and MP for Portsmouth before being forced to retire by gout. He died and was buried at Canterbury.

Sir George Wheler (1651-1724)

Although his mother was from Egerton and his father from Charing, Wheler was born in the Netherlands, where they were living in exile during the Cromwellian Commonwealth. They returned after the Restoration, and Wheler went to school at Wye. After studying at Oxford, he was taken travelling around France, Switzerland, and Italy by his tutor George Hickes. In Venice, he received tuition in antiquities that he put to good use when he went on a tour of classical sites of Greece and the Near East in 1675-6. He brought back artefacts that he donated to Oxford University, as well as botanical specimens, and published an account of his travels called ‘A Journey into Greece’ several years later. In 1677, he was made a Fellow of the Royal Society, but this was rescinded in 1685, by which time he had become a clergyman. He was made a canon at Durham Cathedral, and died at Durham.

Isaac Beckett (1653-1719)

Until mezzotint was invented in Germany in 1642, toned areas in illustrations generally had to be rendered with dots or hatching. This new technique involved roughening the engraved surface so that solid areas could be reproduced more faithfully, greatly enhancing the quality. The technique, which came to rival aquatint, became known in France as la manière anglaise, for which Beckett could take much of the credit. Having started as a calico printer in London, he took up mezzotint with Edward Luttrell, who did most of the drawing while Beckett did the finishing. After marrying a rich woman, he set up his own works, and was particularly prolific in the 1680s. He trained John Smith, who became mezzotint’s leading English exponent. Among the Kent-born Beckett’s most distinguished portraiture subjects were Charles II, the future James II, and the Duke of Buckingham. He also adapted self-portraits by Sir Godfrey Kneller and Sir Peter Lely, both of whom championed mezzotint.

White Kennett (1660-1728)

White Kennett’s unusual name was simply a merge of his parents’ surnames, his father being Basil Kennett, the rector of Dymchurch and vicar of Postling, and his maternal grandfather Thomas White, a wealthy shipbuilder from Dover, where Kennett was himself born. He went to school at Elham and Wye, but failed to complete his education at Westminster School after catching smallpox, and continued privately at Bekesbourne. While studying at Oxford, he took holy orders, eventually reaching the position of Bishop of Peterborough. A strident anti-Papist, he intervened zealously in more than one arcane theological controversy of the day. His greater worth was as an antiquarian. Already as a student he had translated several Latin works into English, among them Erasmus’s ‘In Praise of Folly’, a satire on superstition. Whilst still a vicar in Oxfordshire, he learned Old English and published valuable works on philology, topography, and biography. A street in Aldgate now bears his name.

Admiral of the Fleet George Byng, 1st Viscount Torrington (1663-1733)

Ten years after joining the Royal Navy at 15, George Byng from Wrotham was still an undistinguished lieutenant. In 1688, however, it fell to him to convey to Prince William of Orange the news that certain Navy captains were prepared to transfer their allegiance, leading directly to the Glorious Revolution. Byng was immediately promoted to captain, and under Sir George Rooke participated in the battles of Vigo Bay (1702) and Malaga (1704), as well as the capture of Gibraltar (1704). In 1705, he became MP for Plymouth, and after surviving the Scilly naval disaster of 1707 was made a full admiral. His role in suppressing the Jacobite rebellion of 1715 was rewarded with a baronetcy. Three years later, he stunningly destroyed the Spanish fleet at Cape Passaro and became Admiral of the Fleet. His less fortunate fourth son, Admiral John Byng of Wrotham Park, Middlesex, was infamously executed in order, as Voltaire wrily observed, “to encourage the others”.
